description: Middle English, from earlier corse, from Old French cors, from Latin corpus (“body”).

Displaced native English likam from Old English līċ. The ⟨p⟩ was inserted due to the original Latin spelling. Doublet of corps and corpus. The verb sense derives from the notion of being unable to control laughter while acting as dead body.

entries.meaning: (archaic, sometimes derogatory) A human body in general, whether living or dead.

verbs.description: corpse (third-person singular simple present corpses, present participle corpsing, simple past and past participle corpsed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang, of an actor) To laugh uncontrollably during a performance.
(transitive, slang, of an actor) To cause another actor to do this.
